story.text: Jan 3 The following were the top stories in The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy. * U.S. President George W. Bush defended his deep tax cuts in a Wall Street Journal op-ed, claiming they kept the economy strong while shrinking projected deficits. * China's yuan has crept up 6 percent since July 2005, eroding already thin profit margins for a number of Chinese businesses. * China's Changfeng Motors is displaying vehicles in Detroit this month, highlighting a competitive shift in that country's auto sector. * Funeral services were held for Gerald Ford at Washington's National Cathedral. Bush said in his eulogy that "the world saw the best of America" in the former president. * Nucor Corp. (NUE.N) is buying Harris Steel Group Inc. HSG.TO of Canada for $1.07 billion, marking a break from its nonunion tradition and signalling a bet on industry growth in North America. * Violence in the Niger Delta is alarming big oil companies -- such as Royal Dutch Shell Plc (RDSa.L) and Chevron Corp. (CVX.N) -- that have operations there. * German skilled workers are leaving in record numbers and fewer immigrants are arriving, resulting in skill shortages. * French companies have begun scouring minority communities for talent, an effort that could help ease economic disparities. * The U.S. military is using an emergency-funding request for Iraq to acquire future weapons normally in the regular Pentagon budget. * Lennar Corp. (LEN.N) expects to post a loss of $400 million to $500 million and its chief executive officer said he sees no signs of a home-building recovery.
story.title: press digest - wall street journal - jan 3
